name: Dodge Challenger

overview.history: Modern generation (2008–2023) - The third generation Challenger revived the classic muscle car with modern performance

history: 1970–1974: First generation Challenger introduced as Dodge's answer to the Mustang and Camaro, available in multiple body styles
1978–1983: Second generation Challenger (rebadged Mitsubishi Galant Lambda) - smaller, fuel-efficient model
2008: Third generation Challenger debuts at Chicago Auto Show, reviving the classic muscle car design
2008–2010: Early production years with 5.7L V8 and 6.1L V8 SRT8 models
2011: Introduction of 3.6L Pentastar V6 engine, improving fuel economy while maintaining performance
2015: Major refresh with new 6.4L Scat Pack and 6.2L Hellcat supercharged V8 (717 hp)
2018: Limited production SRT Demon (808 hp) sets world record for fastest production car 0-60 mph
2018–2020: Hellcat Redeye introduced with 797 hp, plus widebody options
2021–2023: Final years with special editions including Last Call series
2023: Final production year with Demon 170 (1025 hp) - the most powerful production muscle car ever made

name: Chevrolet Camaro

overview.history: Six generations of American muscle car, from the original pony car to modern performance machine

history: 1967–1969: First generation Camaro introduced to compete with Ford Mustang, available in multiple body styles and engine options
1970–1981: Second generation with iconic split-bumper design, Z28 performance package, and IROC-Z variants
1982–1992: Third generation with modern fuel injection, IROC-Z becoming a standalone model
1993–2002: Fourth generation with complete redesign, LS1 V8 engine, and SS performance package
2010–2015: Fifth generation revival with retro styling, V6 and V8 options, ZL1 supercharged model
2016–2024: Sixth generation with Alpha platform, lighter weight, improved handling, and track-focused 1LE packages
2017: ZL1 introduced with 650 hp supercharged V8, competing directly with Hellcat and GT500
2018: ZL1 1LE track package adds extreme aerodynamics and suspension for road course dominance
2020: LT1 trim introduced as entry-level V8 option, making 455 hp more accessible
2024: Final model year announced, marking the end of Camaro production after 57 years

name: Ford Mustang

overview.history: The original pony car, continuously produced since 1964, defining the American muscle car segment

history: 1964: Mustang introduced at World's Fair, creating the 'pony car' segment - over 22,000 sold on first day
1965–1973: First generation with multiple body styles, high-performance variants including GT, Mach 1, and Boss 302/429
1974–1978: Second generation Mustang II - smaller, fuel-efficient model responding to oil crisis
1979–1993: Third generation Fox platform with modern unibody construction, 5.0L V8 becoming legendary
1994–2004: Fourth generation with complete redesign, SN95 platform, and New Edge styling refresh
2005–2014: Fifth generation retro-styling revival, S197 platform, reintroduction of GT500 and Boss 302
2015–2023: Sixth generation S550 platform with independent rear suspension, EcoBoost turbo option, and track-focused GT350/GT500
2016: Shelby GT350 introduced with flat-plane crank V8, focused on road course performance
2020: Shelby GT500 debuts with 760 hp supercharged V8, most powerful production Mustang ever
2021: Mach 1 returns as mid-tier performance model, bridging gap between GT and GT500
2024: Seventh generation S650 platform launches with Dark Horse as new performance flagship, continuing Mustang legacy

name: Chevrolet Corvette

overview.history: America's sports car - eight generations of performance, from fiberglass roadster to mid-engine supercar

history: 1953: First generation Corvette introduced at GM Motorama, America's first mass-produced fiberglass sports car
1953–1962: C1 generation with inline-6 and V8 engine options, establishing Corvette as performance icon
1963–1967: C2 Sting Ray with split-window coupe, independent rear suspension, and big-block V8 options up to 427ci
1968–1982: C3 generation with iconic styling, T-top roof option, and performance variants including ZR1 and Z28
1984–1996: C4 generation with complete redesign, digital dashboard, and modern performance technology
1997–2004: C5 generation with LS1 V8 engine, improved handling, and Z06 high-performance variant
2005–2013: C6 generation with LS2/LS3 V8 engines, Z06 with 7.0L V8, and ZR1 with supercharged 6.2L
2014–2019: C7 Stingray with new LT1 V8, Z06 with supercharged 650 hp, and ZR1 with 755 hp
2020: C8 generation debuts with revolutionary mid-engine layout, first production mid-engine Corvette
2020–2024: C8 Stingray establishes new performance benchmarks, Z06 with flat-plane crank V8, E-Ray hybrid
2025: ZR1 announced with twin-turbo V8 producing over 1000 hp, marking pinnacle of Corvette performance

name: BMW M4

overview.history: High-performance coupe from BMW's M division, combining luxury with track-focused engineering

history: 2014: M4 introduced as successor to M3 Coupe, featuring new twin-turbo inline-6 engine
2015–2020: F82 generation establishes M4 as benchmark for luxury sports coupes
2016: M4 GTS limited edition with water injection system, track-focused performance
2018: M4 CS introduced as lighter, more focused variant between Competition and GTS
2021: G82 generation debuts with controversial styling, improved performance and technology
2021–2024: M4 Competition becomes standard bearer with 503 hp and advanced all-wheel drive option
2023: M4 CSL limited edition celebrates 50 years of BMW M, most powerful M4 to date

name: Mercedes-AMG C63

overview.history: AMG's compact performance sedan, known for its thunderous V8 engine and luxury appointments

history: 2008: C63 AMG introduced with naturally aspirated 6.2L V8, replacing C55 AMG
2008–2014: W204 generation establishes C63 as benchmark for compact performance sedans
2012: C63 Black Series limited edition with 510 hp, track-focused aerodynamics
2015: W205 generation debuts with new 4.0L twin-turbo V8, improved efficiency and performance
2016: C63 S Coupe introduced, bringing AMG performance to two-door body style
2015–2021: C63 S becomes flagship with 503 hp, drift mode, and advanced technology
2022: W206 generation transitions to hybrid powertrain, maintaining AMG performance heritage

name: Audi RS5

overview.history: Audi Sport's high-performance coupe, combining quattro all-wheel drive with powerful V8 and V6 engines

history: 2010: First generation RS5 introduced with naturally aspirated 4.2L V8, quattro all-wheel drive
2010–2015: B8 generation establishes RS5 as premium performance coupe
2017: B9 generation debuts with new 2.9L twin-turbo V6, improved efficiency and torque
2018: RS5 Sportback introduced, adding practicality to high-performance formula
2021: RS5 Competition package adds track-focused upgrades and higher top speed
2017–2023: RS5 continues as benchmark for all-wheel drive performance coupes

name: Porsche 911

overview.history: Iconic rear-engine sports car, continuously refined for over 60 years, defining the sports car segment

history: 1964: 911 introduced as successor to 356, establishing rear-engine layout that continues today
1964–1973: Original 911 with air-cooled flat-6 engines, multiple body styles including Targa
1974–1989: G-series with impact bumpers, turbocharging introduced in 1975
1989–1994: 964 generation with all-wheel drive option and modernized technology
1994–1998: 993 generation, last air-cooled 911, Turbo with twin-turbo setup
1998–2004: 996 generation with water-cooled engines, controversial styling
2005–2012: 997 generation returning to classic styling, GT3 and Turbo variants
2012–2019: 991 generation with longer wheelbase, improved handling and performance
2016–2024: 992 generation with new platform, hybrid technology, and advanced aerodynamics
2024: 911 continues as benchmark sports car, balancing tradition with innovation

name: Nissan GT-R

overview.history: Godzilla - Supercar performance at a fraction of the cost, continuously refined for over a decade

history: 2009: R35 GT-R introduced to US market, revolutionizing supercar performance benchmarks
2009–2016: Early R35 establishes GT-R as supercar killer, Nürburgring record holder
2011: GT-R receives power bump to 530 hp, improved transmission programming
2014: GT-R NISMO introduced with 600 hp, track-focused aerodynamics and suspension
2017: GT-R receives major refresh with updated styling, improved interior, and refined performance
2019: 50th Anniversary edition celebrates GT-R heritage with special paint and badging
2009–2024: R35 generation continues as benchmark for accessible supercar performance

name: Toyota Supra

overview.history: Legendary nameplate returns after 20-year hiatus, co-developed with BMW for modern performance

history: 2019: Fifth generation Supra debuts after 20-year hiatus, co-developed with BMW
2019–2024: A90 generation brings modern turbocharged performance to Supra nameplate
2020: 2.0L four-cylinder option introduced for more accessible entry point
2020–2021: A91 Edition special models with unique colors and styling
2022: A91-CF Edition adds carbon fiber accents and special badging
2019–2024: Supra continues to evolve with special editions and refinements

name: Cadillac CT5-V Blackwing

overview.history: America's ultimate performance sedan, combining supercharged V8 power with luxury and track capability

history: 2020: CT5-V introduced as performance variant with twin-turbo V6, replacing ATS-V
2022: CT5-V Blackwing debuts as ultimate performance sedan with 668 hp supercharged V8
2022–2024: Blackwing becomes fastest production Cadillac, setting benchmarks for American performance sedans
2024: Final model year announced, marking end of V8-powered performance sedans from Cadillac

name: Lamborghini Huracán

overview.history: Entry-level supercar from Lamborghini, replacing the Gallardo with V10 power and advanced technology

history: 2014: Huracán debuts at Geneva Motor Show, replacing the Gallardo
2015: Huracán LP 610-4 Spyder introduced with retractable soft top
2017: Performante variant sets Nürburgring lap record for production cars
2019: EVO refresh brings improved aerodynamics and performance
2021: STO (Super Trofeo Omologata) track-focused variant launched
2024: Final V10-powered Huracán models before hybrid transition

name: Ferrari 488

overview.history: Mid-engine V8 supercar replacing the 458 Italia with twin-turbocharged power

history: 2015: 488 GTB debuts at Geneva Motor Show with twin-turbo V8
2015: 488 Spider introduced with retractable hardtop
2018: Pista (track) variant launched with 710 hp
2019: Replaced by F8 Tributo

name: McLaren 720S

overview.history: Flagship supercar from McLaren Automotive with carbon fiber construction and advanced aerodynamics

history: 2017: 720S debuts at Geneva Motor Show, replacing 650S
2019: Spider variant introduced with retractable hardtop
2021: Special editions and track-focused variants released
2024: Production continues as flagship McLaren model

name: Lexus LC 500

overview.history: Luxury grand tourer combining Japanese craftsmanship with V8 performance

history: 2017: LC 500 debuts at North American International Auto Show
2018: Convertible variant introduced
2021: Updated styling and technology features
2024: Continues as flagship Lexus coupe

name: Acura NSX

overview.history: Second-generation NSX with hybrid powertrain and all-wheel drive

history: 2016: Second-generation NSX debuts after 11-year hiatus
2017: Production begins in Ohio, USA
2021: Type S limited edition with 600 hp
2022: Final model year, production ends

name: Honda Civic Type R

overview.history: High-performance front-wheel drive hot hatch with turbocharged power

history: 2017: FK8 generation debuts in North America
2019: Limited edition models and special colors
2022: FL5 generation introduced with updated styling
2024: Continues as flagship Honda performance model

name: Subaru WRX STI

overview.history: All-wheel drive performance sedan with turbocharged boxer engine

history: 2015: Fourth generation WRX STI debuts
2018: Final refresh with updated styling
2021: Final model year, replaced by WRX

name: Mazda RX-7

overview.history: Third-generation rotary-powered sports car, legendary for its unique engine and handling

history: 1993: Third-generation FD RX-7 debuts with sequential twin-turbo system
1995: Final year for base model, R1 track variant introduced
1996: Type RZ variant with 280 hp
2002: Production ends, marking end of rotary sports cars

name: Volkswagen Golf R

overview.history: All-wheel drive hot hatch with turbocharged power and premium features

history: 2015: Mk7 Golf R debuts with 292 hp
2019: Final year for Mk7 generation
2022: Mk8 Golf R introduced with 315 hp
2024: Continues as flagship Golf model

name: Ford GT

overview.history: Modern supercar celebrating 50 years of Ford GT heritage with carbon fiber construction

history: 2017: Second-generation Ford GT enters production
2018: Heritage Edition celebrates racing history
2021: Final production year announced
2022: Production ends after limited run

name: Dodge Viper

overview.history: Fifth-generation V10-powered American supercar, final iteration of the Viper

history: 2013: Fifth-generation Viper debuts with 640 hp
2015: ACR (American Club Racer) track variant introduced
2017: Final model year, production ends

name: Chevrolet Corvette Z06

overview.history: Track-focused variant of the Corvette with enhanced performance and aerodynamics

history: 2015: C7 Z06 debuts with 650 hp supercharged V8
2019: Final year for C7 generation
2023: C8 Z06 introduced with flat-plane V8
2024: Continues as track-focused Corvette

name: Aston Martin Vantage

overview.history: Entry-level sports car from Aston Martin with Mercedes-AMG powertrain

history: 2018: Second-generation Vantage debuts
2021: F1 Edition celebrates Formula 1 partnership
2024: Continues as entry-level Aston Martin

name: Jaguar F-Type

overview.history: British sports car combining luxury with performance, successor to the E-Type

history: 2014: F-Type debuts as successor to E-Type
2016: SVR high-performance variant introduced
2020: Major refresh with updated styling
2024: Final model year announced

name: Genesis G90

overview.history: Flagship luxury sedan from Hyundai's Genesis brand

history: 2017: G90 debuts as Genesis flagship sedan
2019: Major refresh with updated styling
2022: Second generation introduced
2024: Continues as luxury flagship

name: Kia Stinger

overview.history: Rear-wheel drive sports sedan with turbocharged power

history: 2018: Stinger debuts as Kia's first rear-wheel drive sports sedan
2021: Final refresh with updated styling
2023: Final model year, production ends

name: Hyundai Veloster N

overview.history: High-performance hot hatch developed by Hyundai's N division

history: 2019: Veloster N debuts in North America
2021: Power increase to 275 hp
2022: Final model year, replaced by Elantra N

name: Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution

overview.history: Final generation of the legendary all-wheel drive rally-bred sedan

history: 2008: Tenth generation (X) Evo debuts
2011: Final refresh with updated styling
2015: Final Edition marks end of production
2015: Production ends after 25 years

name: Ford Focus RS

overview.history: All-wheel drive hot hatch with drift mode and turbocharged power

history: 2016: Third-generation Focus RS debuts in North America
2017: Limited edition models released
2018: Final model year, production ends

name: Maserati MC20

overview.history: Mid-engine supercar marking Maserati's return to high-performance sports cars

history: 2021: MC20 debuts as Maserati's new flagship supercar
2022: Cielo (convertible) variant introduced
2024: Continues as Maserati's performance flagship
